More information will be posted on our social media sites and website on how to book tours and ticket availability. Wersquore hoping to stay open as long as we can for tours, initially we had planned to open from April with the spirit of Speyside Whisky Festival  run through to September."Our online shop has seen a huge increase and we hope we helped shoppers by adding the Gin  Tonic sets, which are mixers paired with the gin."As well as a range of distilled gins we produce liqueurs including a delicious cold-brew Coffee Liqueur, Cofaidh. Beans are freshlyroasted by Cairngorm Leaf  Bean in Aviemore before we make them into the liqueur. Perfect for making the at home Espresso Martini."As well as the online shop customers can order to send directly to friends  family with a new range of gt cards included covering birthdays, general, and congratulations."www.avvascottishgin----------------------------------------Badachro GinBadachro Distillery is renowned for its range of absolutely delicious, provenance focussed premium gins and rightly proud of its artisan production methods and small batch distillation.Most of the botanicals for Badachro Gin, Coastal Gin, * Storm Strength Gin and very small batch Raspberry Gin and Orangey Orains Gin are hand-picked locally or sourced from within the Highlands and it really tells in the full flavours and very smooth spirit.The small family business started off in  to produce a drink for their bed and breakfast guests and perhaps the local pub. Now it sells gin across the UK in the independent trade and exports to Germany, Denmark, Malta with more quality conscious markets to come.Although gin has been the focus until now, with a slight ersion into rum at times, Badachro Distilleryrsquos first single malt Scotch whisky botting will be released in early August with The Bad na h-Achlasie Collection, first release being a superbly balanced, lightly peated dram, matured in ex-bourbon casks and finished in Tuscan oak red wine casks.You can order onlineat www.badachrodistillery-------------------------------------MINUS An ice-cold GT on a Scottish summerrsquos evening, does it get better than that It seems like it does with Minus , who have concocted a solution to the high calorie content in flavoured gin. The answer is sugar- or rather NO sugar!Gram for gram, alcohol has almost twice as many calories as sugar. Flavoured gin has up to g of added sugar imagine  teaspoons! When you do the maths, the added sugar plus alcohol make a shockingly high calorie count.Minus  is a great tasting, low calorie gin, with a twist made with % natural ingredients, no added sugar or sweeteners with a % ABV. It is also vegan friendly and gluten free.Distilled by the Edinburgh based team, their new flavours have received top reviews from drinkers and bartenders alike.Using naturally sweet botanicals, this delicious spirit could save gin lovers up to  calories per bottle compared to standard flavoured gins.The range includes floral Rose  Peony, classic Juniper Berries, and tropical Passionfruit and Mango gin. Mouth wateringly smooth, you wouldnrsquot believe theyrsquore sugar free! Inidual bottles cost only pound and there are several great deals to be had on their website.Bottles, Gt Bundles, Party Packs and Cases available to order online at minus.Best enjoyed with ice, light tonic and a fruity garnish.--------------------------BLACK THISTLE DISTILLERYBlack Thistle is based in Brechin, among the rolling hills and fertile landscapes of the county of Angus ndash an area renowned for producing the finest fruits, freshest water, and of course the highest quality botanicals Scotland has to offer. We do not compromise on the key ingredients for our range of smooth, and sumptuous gins.The genesis of our gin begins in our recipe development lab we deliberate, iterate, taste and repeat, creating over a hundred recipes in the pursuit of perfection, and we think we are pretty close.From the original Black Thistle Gin, to our misted range, we have blended such classic combinations as orange and cinnamon through to the less common heather and liquorice with outstanding feedback. Not only do they look breathtaking they taste breathtaking too.And we do not stop there ndash at Black Thistle we are constantly in the pursuit of new and interesting flavour combinations. Our latest launch is our Green Mist ndash a mint and kiwi gin that will tease your taste buds and leave you feeling refreshed and revitalised.What will be next  That remains to be seen, but rest assured it will be delicious and it will be soon.We take much care in scaling our gin from our lab stills to our beautul l Carl Copper stills. We run our gins through eight slow and steady stages of distillation making our cuts with the precision that only experience can grant.Every bottle is hand bottled and undergoes loving and rigorous quality assurance checks. The resulthellip well the result is something thatrsquos dficult to put to words. You will have to go and try it for yourself.Seeblackthistledistilleries-----------------------------------House of Elrick ginNestled in the rich, rural tapestry within the lowlands of Aberdeenshire, the House of Elrick is the source of a delicious range of premium quality spirits.House of Elrickrsquos signature gin is crisp and fragrant. The botanicals, hand-picked by their Master of Gin are a complement of juniper, coriander seeds, angelica root and citrus peel, built around a core of heather, pink peppercorns, sweet fennel and rose petals.Refreshing and aromatic, House of Elrick Gin is a spirit made with the essence of Scotland, using local ingredients and the crisp waters of Loch Ness. It is a fresh and vibrant infusion. The versatility of the gin means that it can be enjoyed on the rocks, or as the foundation of your favourite gin-based cocktail.At the House of Elrick, quality over quantity is key. Distilled by hand in batches of  bottles per run, means distillers can maintain control over every bottle that leaves the distillery. Botanicals are handpicked before each distillation through their bespoke pot still.Members of the Elrick Estate note that a perfect serve for their signature gin would be served on the rocks or with a fine, quality tonic from a deep wine glass to retain the aromas. When it comes to garnishing, they recommend you opt for aromatic orange zest. The orange will accent the fragrance and intensy the rose and peppercorns notes.The lines of gin and rum are made at the Elrick estate, within the garden walls of a home veiled in mystery and tradition. Built at the height of the Scottish Enlightenment period in , the house boasts a rich history.As the restoration project continues, the team welcomes you to indulge in a drink and share their journey and will open as a venue for weddings and events later this year.houseofelrickwww.facebook houseofelrick-------------------------------------Tiree GinThe latest addition from Tiree Whisky Company , Hebridean Pink Gin is distilled and bottled on the Isle of Tiree, the outermost of the Inner Hebridean islands.Tiree is a fertile and remote island, famed for sunshine and stunning scenery, and is surrounded by the vast Atlantic Ocean. In the eighteenth century, the island was home to around fty distillers with each farm on the island operating at least one still producing whisky.This began to decline as tighter regulations from both the estate and the government were introduced. Although a large number of islanders were still making whisky illegally, this industry ceased completely in the nineteenth century.#Tiree Whisky Company Ltd was established by locals Alain Campbell and Ian Smith with the aim of reviving the spirit industry on an island with a rich heritage in the tradition.Local production of Tyree Gin began in February  and, once again, the island was home to an operational distillery - the first in  years.Hebridean Pink Gin is distilled with juniper, raspberries and sweet peels. The stunning bottle was designed by Glasgow based design agency, O Street, and the striking design certainly catches the eye.Pre-order available with delivery from thJuly.www.hebrideanpinkgin---------------------------------Pentlands Hills GinNestled deep in the western Pentland Hills, Tarbraxus Distillers is home to the award-winning Pentland Hills Gin.The company was created by Phil and Tabatha who set about delivering not just a first-class gin, but a gin thatrsquos distilled in the most sustainable fashion possible.The gin reflects the le they live in the hills first up, however, you have to meet Panza, the chocolate Labrador who is the CEO .The Companyrsquos original gin is distilled using nine botanicals, some of which are grown around the farm. Double distilled in a copper still called Amy, the gin offers a very smooth impression on first sipping.For some the taste of citrus will emerge, for others maybe a hint of aniseed or cocoa. This % abv gin is full of surprises. Served with pink grapefruit it makes a delicious GT. In a martini, the gin offers the perfect  moment.The gin is also offered at Navy Strength ndash % abv. Despite this big mouthful of alcohol, it is remarkably smooth and can be happily sipped naked! As a GT it offers hints of toffee and citrus, for the adventurous try mixing a Vesper ndash you wonrsquot be disappointed.Sustainability drives Phil and Tabatharsquos ethos. The distillery uses solar energy, water rises on the land and juniper has been planted to help the regeneration of the berry which is key to all gin distillation.Perhaps the greatest innovation is the lsquobottle for lersquo approach to the way the gin is sold. You buy your first etched bottle and it is marked with your personal number. When itrsquos time to replace the gin you post is back .Even better your gin bottle can be switched from Original to Navy gin and back as you wish. As Panza says, lsquoitrsquos a woofingly good idea!rsquoThe gin is produced in tiny qualitiessoyoursquore lucky enough to own a bottle enjoy every drop and then have it refilled by people who really care about how they create and deliver your tipple.www.pentlandhillsginor #PentlandHillsGin @PentlandHillsGin @PentlandGin-----------------------------Esker SpiritsA family-run business led by husband  we team, Steven  Lynne Duthie, Esker Spirits has evolved from a kitchen hobby, to distilling in the shed before, in April , moving to premises in the beautul Kincardine Estate on Royal Deeside, Aberdeenshire. And itrsquos here in Royal Deeside where the inspiration for Esker Spirits comes from ndash all the spirits contain the sap from silver birches which are everywhere around the distillery.Says Lynne: ldquoWe have our own distillery ndash and make, bottle, deliver and enjoy our gins. All our gins are full flavoured ndash there is no relying on mixers or garnish for flavour, itrsquos all packed into the gin.Photo: The Gin Cooperative LtdAll of Eskerrsquos gins start in the same way with classic gin botanicals and the Esker twist ndash silver birch sap from the Kincardine Estate. Distilling days start early, using traditional copper stillsto make the gin ndash the smell in the distillery when they are working is incredible.Esker Gin is the flagship ndash a classic London Dry gin, great in a gin and tonic with ice and a twist of orange zest, it is a beautully smooth gin. Esker, along with its sister gin, Esker Goldhave won IWSC Gold Medals and Great Taste stars.Photo: The Gin Cooperative LtdThe flavour profile of Esker Gin is smooth, clean and juniper led. This classic gin has its own distinctive notes with over a dozen botanicals, locally sourced silver birch sap, citrus and a hint of the floral botanicals.In addition to Esker Gold, the range also includes the Silverglas gins ndash a light, fresh London dry, and two fruit gins, Scottish Raspberry Gin and Valencian Orange Gin. The fruit gins are made with real fruit, not syrups or cordials. ldquoItrsquos a lot of work, but worth it for the end product, Lynne adds.Photo: The Gin Cooperative LtdBuilding on the brand, and tapping into the market for lighter, fruit flavoured drinks, Esker Spirits has recently lived up to its name by extending the spirits range to include two fruit vodkas .Of the future, Lynne says: ldquoWe are focusing on building our brand and making it easier for our customers to find our spirits on the shelf ndash whether they are in a shop, or in a bar. There is always some development work going on at the distillery so you never know when new products might start appearinghellip watch this space!www.eskerspiritsFacebook: @eskerspiritsInstagram: @eskerspiritsTwitter: @esker_spirits----------------------------Red Door GinRed Door Gin is carefully handcrafted at Benromach Distillery in Forres, where every drop is distilled in ldquoPeggy ndash the small copper pot behind the distilleryrsquos iconic red door.Launched in , Red Door has already won a Gold Medal at the Gin Masters with the  of expert judges commenting on the ginrsquos ldquochocolatey nose, earthy taste, woody, rooty notes and a little liquorice sweetness. Delicate enough to sip and savour neat, perfect with fresh raspberries in a classic GT or packing a punch in a classic cocktail, this is a gin that can do it all.Focusing on quality over quantity, the distillery produces two ieties ndash Red Door Highland Ginor Red Door Gin with Winter Botanicals . Both are equally delicious and itrsquos impossible to pick a favourite.For those with a real thirst for gin knowledge, be sure to put the Red Door Gin Visitor Experience on your staycation to-do list . With only eight spaces per tour, this is a chance for visitors to learn first-hand about the history of the distillery and how each batch of handcrafted ndash and award-winning ndash Highland gin is made.Housed behind the distilleryrsquos iconic red door, this one hour tour will bring the distillation process to le while introducing guests to ldquoPeggy ndash the small copper pot still where every batch of Red Door Gin is carefully handmade by the on-site team.After learning about botanicals and distillation, visitors can make their way to the Red Door Gin bar to sample the perfect Red Door GT or signature cocktail. Itrsquos on the site of Benromach Distillery, so while yoursquore there why not pop in to learn about this iconic Speyside single malt too  Itrsquos the only distillery in Speyside to offer gin and whisky visitor attractions at one site and is well worth a visit.Red Door Highland Gin and Red Door Gin with Winter Botanicals are available from www.reddoorgin our-shop for pound. cl.------------------------------Teasmith GinItrsquos been a busy year for The Teasmith Gin creators Nick and Emma Smalley. The makers of the first Scottish Gin distilled with hand-picked tea have been slowly expanding their list of stockists across Scotland and the UK. saw them collect another swathe of awards including the Spirits Business Masters Medal for their packaging and design of their flagship product The Teasmith Original. They also released Broich Single Estate ndash a limited edition gin featuring tea grown right here in Scotland.Why tea  Because Scotland has many historical links with the tea trade with several stemming from Aberdeenshire which is where the Founders are based. When they discovered the story of James Taylor ndash a young man from the area - who grew the very first commercial tea plantation in British Ceylon, they worked with tea consultant Beverly Wainwright to source a special loose leaf tea from the Amba Estate in Sri Lanka.It is both hand-picked and hand-rolled ndash much in the same way Taylor produced his first batches  years ago on the island.When distilled, the tea provides fabulous citrus notes of blood orange along with a minty sweetness. These flavours are paired with more classic gin botanicals such as juniper, coriander seed, dried orange peel, angelica and orris root and a sprinkle of rose petals to create a smooth and fresh juniper-led gin with a citrusy lingering sweetness.The Teasmith Gin doesnrsquot disappoint. A truly smooth classic dry style gin packaged in a beautully simple bottle with lots of hidden hand-finishes ndash it ticks all the boxes.Serve this gin with copious ice, a premium quality tonic and sprig of fresh mint for a truly crisp and refreshing GT. The founders used their recent time in lockdown to completely refresh their website and provide a nice range of cocktail suggestions too! So check out the dferent ways you could enjoy The Teasmith Gin this summer.The Teasmith Gin is available through The Teasmith Ginrsquos website for pound. or through the Master of Malt. Available in store at The Good Spirit Coand Royal Mile Whiskiesand many other stockists listed on their website.Instagram:@the_teasmithTwitter: @the_teasmithFacebook:  theteasmithginFor more information, visit www.teasmithgin

title: professor-geoff-palmer-compares-scottish-independence-independence-former-british-colonies
story: Professor Geoff Palmer was speaking to Channel  last night when hesaid seeking independence or control of a countryrsquos affairs was part of a statersquos ldquonatural progressions.The human rights activist and emeritus professor at Edinburghrsquos Heriot-Watt University said eventually, all nations will want to manage their own affairs.He said: ldquoIrsquom from Jamaica and Jamaica has had a long history with Britain, we joined in  and Jamaica got her independence in  and Jamaica still has a link with Britain.:Ian Blackford: Boris Johnson must allow independence referendumSNP win Holyrood majority"So I see one of the natural progressions of all nations, of all nations of people, that eventually one day they will start to think about lsquowell, we want to manage our own affairsrsquo."Itrsquos a union, yes, from about , but Scotland goes back a lot longer than that. Therefore it is about not just from , itrsquos beyond that and therefore it is about a group of people of which I am a part."Scotland is a erse society, we regard ourselves as one Scotland and I think this is the debate and I think the public should decide."I think where we have a thing called public opinion, and when that in fact indicates that the public wants something, I think we should do it.:Brits say relationship between Scotland and England is weaker than it was five years agoHe was asked by Channel s Krishnan Guru-Murthy whether he saw Scottish independence as an "inevitability".In response, he said he was sure the country would decide one way or another.He said: ldquoI think inevitability doesnrsquot come into politics. Politics is about what seems best at the time and I think just as Jamaica got independence after  years, Irsquom sure Scotland will decide one way or another when the time comes and when the public wants it and I think Scotland will do what the public wants.

title: uk-government-rejects-kate-forbes-calls-flexible-powers-following-1-9bn-extra-covid-funding
story: Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Steve Barclay, has claimed the extra funding for Scotland, taking the total to pound. billion during the pandemic, was in response to a request from the Scottish Government.But Scottish Finance Secretary, Kate Forbes, said the additional powers would "not cost the UK Government a penny" and that Westminsters stance was "disappointing".Mr Barclay spoke to MsForbes on Friday, hours after she again asked for greater flexibility on fiscal matters and the ability to borrow more.Similar repeated requests have been made, including one alongside the finance ministers in Wales and Northern Ireland, who also took part in the discussion with Mr Barclay,but all were turned down.Mr Barclay said: ldquoWhat the Scottish Government said is that they wanted greater flexibility to be able to deal with some of the uncertainty of the pressures from Covid and they gave us an estimate as to what that cost would be.ldquoWersquove listened to that and wersquove responded with something thatrsquos not been done before, which is giving that in-year clarity as to the additional Covid funding for the rest of the year.After the pound. billion of extra funding was announced, Ms Forbes welcomed the help - but stressed it changed nothing about the need for more flexible financial powers to be handed over.:Ian Blackford: Boris Johnson must allow independence referendumSNP win Holyrood majorityMs Forbes added that the Scottish Government is "still deprived" of the borrowing powers the UK Government has at its disposal, stressing that "we need agreement on fiscal flexibilities".Mr Barclay questioned how Scotland would borrow the extra funding it seeks.He said: ldquoItrsquos dficult to see even what currency the Scottish Government would be borrowing under. The UK, through pooling its resources, is able to borrow at low interest rates.ldquoThrough the block grant, Scotland benefits in terms of its funding ndash pound per head compared to pound in England.ldquoBut the measures today are in addition to that and they sit within the wider package of UK support, and thatrsquos because across the UK wersquore better able to weather the storm of the Covid crisis.:Kate Forbes joins forces with Welsh and Northern Irish counterparts in plea for powersWhen asked about the prospect of Scottish independence or another referendum on the issue in the near future, the Chief Secretary echoed comments made by Prime Minister Boris Johnson when he visited Scotland on Thursday that the union has worked for Scotland and the rest of the UK in the response to Covid-.Mr Barclay also highlighted that  per cent of Scottish trade is with the rest of the UK, but when askedan independent Scotland could make a trade deal with the rest of the UK in the same way the UK Government is currently attempting to with the European Union, he said: ldquoThe question would be for the Scottish Government as to what sort of trading relationship they were hoping to secure.Mr Barclay also claimed the people of the UK want to see politicians ldquocoming together to protect jobs and the economy during the pandemic.MsForbessaid:ldquoIf we are to meet the challenges of coronavirus,we also require additional fiscal flexibility and it is disappointing the UK Government failed to agree to this today.ldquoThe powers we and the other devolved governments seek are reasonable, straightforward and would not cost the UK Government a penny.She added:ldquoAt the moment, for example, I canrsquot take money from the capital budget, which we have been unable to spend because of Covid-, anduse it for revenue. Yet it is revenue that pays for our health services and schools, supports businesses and keeps our transport systems running.ldquoUnlike other countries across the world we cannot respond quickly to emerging needs by borrowing, leaving us overly-dependent on policy decisions made by the UK Government.

title: renewable-energy-push-fresh-wind-sails
story: The debate over a green restart to the Scottish economy is taking place as we head towards rsquos Earth Overshoot Day, on  August. Having an array of successful and ongoing renewables projects will also play well for Scotland as it looks to host COP-, the United Nations th Climate Change Conference, from November  to  next year, at the Glasgow SECC.Of course, not all green projects will be renewable energy projects. The UK Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, for example, recently announced a pound billion lsquogreen investmentrsquo package as part of the UK governmentrsquos COV- recovery plan, but this was all about improving the insulation of public buildings and cutting emissions from Britainrsquos poorly insulated homes.This announcement was immediately slammed as lsquotoo littlersquo and lsquotoo unambitiousrsquo. Greenpeace pointed out that the German government has committed pound billion into climate-change preventative measures, while France has committed pound. billion.Scotland has an even more ambitious target than Westminster and aims to achieve a net-zero economy by . In this it has been greatly aided by the UK Governmentrsquos decision, in early March to do a U-turn on its four year old ban on onshore wind farm subsidies. That ban, put in place by the then Prime Minister, David Cameron, caused a sharp decline in the number of new onshore wind farms.According to Scottish Renewables, today, onshore wind already has some GW of capacity in new developments that have achieved planning consent. Another GW of projects are currently in the planning process. Offshore wind too, had GW of projects with planning consent.Morag Watson, Director of Policy at Scottish Renewables, said: ldquoScotlandrsquos renewable energy industry provides enormous opportunity to deliver a green economic recovery and address the challenges created by the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoOnshore wind ndash the cheapest form of new power generation ndash can play a huge role in this. The technology currently provides more than % of Scotlandrsquos renewable energy capacity , displacing millions of tonnes of carbon each year. The sector employs , people across the country and brings skilled jobs and investment to some of our most remote communities.ldquoAs the windiest country in Europe, there is massive opportunity to increase deployment of onshore wind and continue to harness the socio-economic benefits of doing so, whilst working towards a net-zero energy future, she comments.Solar and marine power projects are also at an exciting stage, with MW of solar projects at ious stages of development and MW of wave and tidal projects either already consented or in planning.Scottish Power chief executive Keith Anderson says that the energy giant now has plans for a major expansion of its onshore wind projects, with up to GW of new installations planned. He points out that the energy companyrsquos onshore wind farm projects can serve as a catalyst for launching a lsquogreen recoveryrsquo.Energy firm Vattenfall is close to adding the pound million -turbine South Kyle wind farm in Southern Scotland to its renewable energy portfolio. The project is expected to complete by  and will be able to power around , homes, saving nearly , tonnes of carbon emissions annually.The firm has two more wind farms planned for the area, including the Quantans Hill and Whiteneuk farms. Frank Elsworth, Vattenfallrsquos UK Development Director for Onshore Wind, commented: ldquoSouth West Scotland has the potential to become a green energy hub. South Kyle, Quantans Hill and Whiteneuk can play a major part in helping to power Scotland towards net zero and provide green shoots of recovery from the economic damage of Covid-.A recent report from Aberdeen University has added to the lsquogreen powerrsquo theme by highlighting the potential for oil and gas companies to use marine renewable technologies like wave power to lower their carbon footprint.At the same time, Crown Estates Scotland has launched the first offshore wind leasing round in a decade. The ScotWind round is expected to unlock some  billion of investment and result in the development of ten commercial wind farms off the coast of Scotland.Martin Valenti, Head of Climate Enterprise at Scottish Enterprise points out that focusing money and planning on the creation of green jobs could unlock a whole range of new employment opportunities.ldquoIt might seem odd to specy lsquogreenrsquo jobs at a time when any job is important, but we need to think ahead. We canrsquot just go back to where we were. There are a host of opportunities in the new, green space, he says.Valenti argues that it will be a huge coupScotland can demonstrate by COP- that it has demonstrable successes in its efforts to transition to a low carbon economy, capable of delivering environmental success.ldquoThis is where our partnership with the Scottish Environmental Protection Agency and other bodies hold so much promise. We have to start working in partnership with the environment, within planetary constraints rather than with growing ecological debt, he says.Valenti points out that a major expansion in Scotlandrsquos exploration of the hydrogen economy has the potential to reduce carbon emissions dramatically. Transitioning to hydrogen for heating in homes and offices, and as an alternative transport fuel would have a huge impact in lowering Scotlandrsquos carbon footprint, he notes.Using renewable power to produce the hydrogen would result in a major win-win for both renewables and hydrogen projects.Valenti points out too, that there could even be an opportunity for Scotland to regain its former glory as a shipbuilding nation,it could successfully demonstrate the deployment of hydrogen as an alternative fuel for shipping. There is already a successful hydrogen-powered ferry pilot project running in Orkney and the Northern Isles.The Scottish Council for Development and Industry, a unique coalition of business, government and third sector organisations, recently produced a report with practical ideas for government on how to launch a green restart. The report prioritises investment in renewable power along as well as urging investment in innovative projects that will help to move Scotland towards its zero-carbon targets.Sara Thiam, SCDI Chief Executive, comments: ldquoScotland has the potential to be a leader in lsquoclean growth. COP-, in particular, offers Scotland a very exciting opportunity to showcase its environmental successes on a global stage.ldquoBy shining a light on the big innovations we are producing, we can encourage the inward investment of patient capital into our large scale green infrastructure projects, such as offshore wind generation and new technologies yet to be developed she comments.James Stewart, Deputy Director, Centre for Energy Policy, Strathclyde University, sounds a cautionary note on the theme of green jobs versus any jobs. ldquoGreen options need to be able to stand up against all other recovery options. We canrsquot do it for greens sake. However, the more new green jobs we can create the easier it will be to meet our climate targets in future, he says.This article appeared in The Herald as part of our  part editorial series in support of Earth Overshoot day. Our next  topics are looking at who we produce and dispose of food, natural resources and population.To particiapte please contact Stephen McTaggart on  EMAIL:stephen.mctaggart@heraldandtimes

title: tom-gordon-looming-election-brings-sturgeons-shelf-life-fore
story: Congratulations, First Minister. Enjoy it. Yoursquoll be  in no time.If you think thatrsquos a little harsh, donrsquot. Politicians are always thinking ahead like that, as we saw in the recent flurry of MSPs announcing their exit at next yearrsquos Holyrood election.ldquoI will be  this summer and  at the end of the next parliament, sighed the SNPrsquos Mike Russell as he waved farewell to his Argyll  Bute seat.Labourrsquos Iain Gray felt the same shudder of tempus fugit in East Lothian: ldquoThe decision to stand down is not an easy onehellip however I will be  next year, almost  by the end of the next parliament.The First Minister also showed her dread of a drive-by shooting from timersquos winged chariot in interviews on the occasion on her birthday.ldquoI am a bit perplexed as how, suddenly, Irsquom , she said in one.ldquoI think, with politicians, there must be something about living in four or five -year election cycles - suddenly four of them have gone past and thatrsquos  years of your le.It wasnrsquot the only interesting thing she said. In another birthday piece, she spoke about le after power.ldquoWhile Irsquom not planning for it to be imminent, whenever I do stop being first minister ndash because every first minister has a shelf le ndash I will still be young enough, and hopefully healthy enough, to go in a dferent direction and do other things. I find that is something that is quite uplting.Itrsquos always intriguing when leaders broach their political mortality.:Boris Johnson and Nicola Sturgeon both need to grow up as Prime Minister visits ScotlandCan you imagine Ms Sturgeon in her pomp after the  general election raising the prospect of le after politics  It wasnrsquot so much as a dot on the horizon back then.Now itrsquos not just on her mind. The thought of embarking on a new career is actually ldquoquite uplting.Clearly doing a five year stretch in Bute House transforms the soul.So letrsquos consider what the next electoral cycle or two might bring.Although most commentary right now is about the coronavirus and the constitution dominating the  vote, and whether Indyref or economic recovery takes priority, I suspect another big strand will be the shelf le Ms Sturgeon mentioned.She will have been First Minister for six and half years on election day, and will be asking for up to five more.That would take her to just  days shy of Margaret Thatcherrsquos marathon rise and fall of  and a half years.Ms Sturgeon is therefore bound to be asked ad nauseam in the campaignshe would serve out a full term.As her partyrsquos buoyant popularity is inextricably bound up with her own ratings, she would have little option but to say that she would, with gusto.But would Ms Sturgeon follow through on her pledge Bear in mind it implies she would try to outdo Mrs Thatcher by standing again at the  election as well, as she wouldnrsquot have given her party time to pick a new leader before then.:Nicola Sturgeons top official first to be grilled by Alex Salmond inquiryThoughts of her shrinking shelf-le and the Enoch Powell adage that all political careers end in failure would surely be crowding in by that point.The next Holyrood term or two will be unforgiving. The economic pain left by Covid will be long and grim.Deep recessions and popular governments are rarely seen in each otherrsquos company.It will be an extraordinary slog. Or rather, another extraordinary slog.Nor is there much sign of relief on the independence front. Even another SNP majority is not going to melt Boris Johnsonrsquos self-interested heart.He does not want to risk a second referendum and have the end of the Union on his political headstone.With Labour recovering under Sir Keir Starmer, Mr Johnsonrsquos best electoral days already seem behind him. Given the Tory partyrsquos ruthless form with maling leaders hersquoll be lucky to last a couple of years.No need to make the inevitable more wretched by losing Scotland into the bargain. His successor wonrsquot want to start with Indyref either.Which means that, on top of the economic problems, Ms Sturgeon can expect years of anger from the Yes movement about the lack of a plan to overcome Westminsterrsquos entirely predictable referendum blocking.In truth, the muttering and mumping is pretty loud already.Butthe th anniversary of  arrives without a big change in outlook, it will become deafening.However there is an escape clause in Powellrsquos famous quote.It reads in full: ldquoAll political lives, unless they are cut off in midstream at a happy juncture, end in failure, because that is the nature of politics and of human affairs.So far, no First Minister of Scotland has found that happy juncture.Death and defeat have been the way, then obscurity or notoriety.Donald Dewar died after barely a year in office. Henry McLeish quit over an expenses fiasco. Jack McConnell lost the  election. Alex Salmond lost the referendum.Could Ms Sturgeon be the first to do it her way  Might she decide that, given her inevitable expiry date, a fresh start is best begun at a time of her choosing, rather than be forced out of office on a bum note In less than two electoral cycles she really will be , and that window to a dferent le will be closing fast.I wonder... Anyway, from an envious -year-old, Happy Birthday.

title: lisa-mackenzie-harnessing-elements-power-new-age-clean-energy
story: The islands of Orkney where we are based are blessed with abundant renewable energy resources. On the odd days that the wind isnrsquot blowing, the waves are crashing against our shores, and tides flow from the North Sea to the Atlantic Ocean every six hours ndash as predictable as clockwork.EMEC was set up in  to enable wave and tidal energy technologies ndash machines that harness the power of the sea ndash to test in the ocean. The resources in Orkney truly put these machines to the test with waves of over  metres ndash imagine standing next to a six-storey building ndash and a peak tidal flow of around eight knots ndash thatrsquos approximately half a billion tonnes of water passing through our tidal site an hour. The technologies testing with us not only have to survive these extreme conditions but generate power from.EMECs Operations Technician performing maintenance on the Hydrogen plant on EdayEMEC is essentially a plug-and-play facility set up to reduce the cost, time and risk of testing offshore with pre-consented grid-connected sites. And to date, we have hosted more ocean energy technologies than any other site in the world.One of the more recent demonstrations was by a local Orkney-based company, Orbital Marine Power. Their floating tidal turbine generated over  GWh of renewable electricity over the course of a year, producing around % of Orkneyrsquos electricity needs. Thatrsquos one day a fortnight that Orkney was running on tidal electricity produced by just one prototype. Orbital are currently working on the next iteration of their turbine, due to be demonstrated at EMEC early .Wersquore also working on projects to help progress floating offshore wind, supporting the development of an offshore test site in Ireland to demonstrate a floating wind technology. We work closely with ious other countries around the world to help them realise their own ocean energy potential and instigate the development of a global market for our clients and the wider sector.Ocean energy testing is what EMEC is best known for, however our operations have developed signicantly through the years as wersquove found our infrastructure, skills and knowledge are in demand for progressing other low-carbon technologies as well.Today wersquore also pioneering the development of a green hydrogen economy here in Orkney. When recreated using renewable power, hydrogen is a carbon neutral fuel as it does not emit carbon when burnt.Due to local grid constraints, which continue to pose a barrier to Orkney realising its full renewables potential, we set up an onshore hydrogen production plant next to our tidal energy substation. In  we generated the worldrsquos first tidal-powered hydrogen.This has led to us working on a range of pioneering hydrogen projects, from generating hydrogen using tidal energy, to decarbonising Orkneyrsquos leline services, and even looked into hydrogen-powered gin.As an example, the HyFlyer project is garnering a lot of interest at the moment as it gears up for its maiden -mile hydrogen-powered flight from Orkney later in . The project aims to decarbonise medium-range small passenger aircraft by demonstrating powertrain technology to replace conventional piston engines in propeller aircraft. The conventional powertrain in the aircraft is being replaced with electric motors, hydrogen fuel cells and gas storage.Wersquore also involved in wider energy systems demonstration projects. Microsoft deployed a kW subsea data centre at our wave test site in . The project is part of Microsoftrsquos ongoing quest for cloud data centre solutions that are less resource intensive and offer rapid provisioning, lower costs, and high agility to meet the needs of cloud users around the world.Deepwater deployment offers ready access to cooling, a controlled environment, and has the potential to be powered by co-located renewable power sources, such as the pioneering wave and tidal energy technologies testing nearby at EMECrsquos test sites.EMEC is also leading an exciting new project called ReFLEX Orkney looking to decarbonise the wider energy system. ReFLEX aims to integrate electricity, transport and heat systems in Orkney using clever software coupled with an increase of flexible demand assets like batteries and electric vehicles.This will help Orkney maximise the potential of its renewable energy resource, provide more affordable energy services, and lower the countyrsquos carbon footprint by decreasing reliance on imported carbon-intensive grid electricity from the UK mainland.EMEC was set up to kick start an ocean energy sector in the UK and boost economic development in the Highlands and Islands, and while ocean energy is very much still at the heart of what we do, we are now using our infrastructure, skills and know-how to help the world decarbonise in other areas as well ndash and demonstrate the clean energy system of the future.This article appeared in The Herald as part of our  part editorial series in support of Earth Overshoot day. Our next  topics are looking at who we produce and dispose of food, natural resources and population.To particiapte please contact Stephen McTaggart on  EMAIL:stephen.mctaggart@heraldandtimes

title: scottish-universities-wont-know-next-years-covid-19-impact-students-turn-dont
story: The alarm comes as a new report from the Scottish Parliament Information Centre , indicates that the coronavirus pandemic ldquowill have an impact on universities for the foreseeable future despite some campuses being able to begin re-opening a few days ago.The industry is expected to lose around pound million from the last academic year, according to the Scottish Funding Council , but a deficit of up to pound million could face Scottish universities in the   year ndash with much of the loss due to the lack of overseas fee-paying students attending from September.The Institute for Fiscal Studieshas estimated that Scottish universities could lose as much as pound.bn in the long run, and the impact on the UK-wide sector could be anywhere between pound billion and pound billion.:Coronavirus: Scottish universities could have to curtail research ambitions amid funding reviewThe SFC indicates that in an optimistic scenario with the number of new international students cut in half and a  per cent reduction of international students continuing studies, ldquothe projected collective operating deficit is pound. million.But a more pessimistic scenario where no new international students are able to attend Scottish universities from September, ldquothe collective operating deficit is pound million. A total of  Scottish universities are expected to report budget deficits in the   academic year.The SPICe research indicated that as the new academic year approaches in September, ldquothe sector will face new and considerable financial challenges, adding to existing pressures.It adds: ldquoA fall in international student numbers is expected to be one of the main drivers behind the fall in income. This is of particular concern given tuition fees make up the largest proportion of sector income at  per cent and within that, international student fees make up  per cent of tuition fee income .ldquoHowever, the latest UCAS applicant figures up to June  show a  per cent rise in international applicants to Scottish universities and final entrant figures will not be known until the new academic year starts in September. "It is therefore dficult to know at this stage how much income will be lost.:Coronavirus: Fears universities could be mergedthey dont embrace new normalScottish universities have an income of almost pound billion a year - with around half from the Scottish and UK Governments. Around pound billion is tallied up in fees from non-EU students and from other parts of the UK.Alastair Sim, director of Universities Scotland, said: "The report is absolutely right to say that Scottish universities face a considerable financial challenge as a result of Covid-. Even the most optimistic estimate puts losses at over pound million in the next academic year so the stakes are very high indeed."The report rightly highlights that tuition fees, and particularly fees from international students, are the largest source of income for universities and recognises that a fall, of any size, in the number of students coming to Scotland will have a serious impact on university finances.He added: ldquoWersquore months into this crisis but the reality is that universities wonrsquot know the impact on demand until students turn up ndash or donrsquot. Recent applicant data has been a cause for cautious optimism within the sector, in that applications are better than originally feared, when it comes to international students these figures are partial and only indicative.Universities have been propped up by pound million of Scottish Government funding for research, while the UK Government announced a UK-wide pound million research and innovation pot of cash, alongside grant funding and low interest loans.The Scottish Government has also announced that free tuition fees for non-UK EU students will be ended after the   academic year ndash with Universities Minister Richard Lochhead stressing that the estimated pound million that would have funded new EU students studying in Scotland will instead be used to fund places for Scottish students.Mr Sim added: ldquoWersquore grateful for the support packages already offered by the Scottish and UK Governments which will go some way to protect university research and innovation. That support is positive recognition that research and innovation will have a key role in the recovery.ldquoHowever, the pandemic has also been hugely disruptive to the many sources of income that underpin teaching in our universities.ldquoItrsquos that teaching which contributes the skills and knowledge needed for the post-pandemic economy so wersquore concerned that this remains on the agenda and we move into next academic year ndash which is when the financial pressures will be felt most acutely by universities.Some Scottish universities are more reliant than others on international students as a key part of their business model. Before the Covid- crisis hit, Heriot-Watt University has around  Chinese students and also has campuses in Dubai and Malaysia.Some institutions were facing financial constraints before the Covid- pandemic arrived, with SFC funding having reduced by seven per cent, or pound million, in real terms between - and -.Mr Lochhead has previously warned that Scottish universities must change their financial model and "become much more resilient" warning that "theres hard lessons to learn".He added: ldquoWe have to find a way of tapping into the global reputation our institutions have ndash our universities are respected throughout the world and understandably, we have capitilised on that as a nation.ldquoWe do have to look at have a much more resilient financial model and we have to look at how overall, our colleges and universities can be better protected from these global events in the future."

title: scottish-government-fast-track-laws-crackdown-airbnb-style-short-term-lets
story: The Scottish Government had put its plans to introduce a licensing regime on hold amid the Covid- pandemic, along with a raft of other legislation that will not see the light of day before next yearrsquos Holyrood election.But Housing Minister Kevin Stewart will fast track handing new powers over to councils in the coming months ndash with the intention that the new regulations are in place before Holyrood is dissolved for next yearrsquos poll.While the licensing rules, which could include local authorities being handed the power to set up ldquoshort-term let control areas under planning regulations, will be welcomed by authorities in Edinburgh, tourism bosses in Skye, which has an even higher concentration of the controversial accommodation, havewarned businesses do not want ldquoan additional administrative burden for next season.In Edinburgh, evidence suggests the explosion of short term lets is contributing to a housing crisis ndash with the fall in available homes for rent coinciding with the surge in Airbnb listings.In the capitalrsquos city centre, more housing stock is now available for short term lets than for traditional private rented homes.A report has also suggested that only one in  Airbnb listings in Edinburgh have planning permission.Council officials in the capital pleaded with short term let owners to hand over their properties to help shelter the cityrsquos homeless population during the Covid- lockdown, but a licensing regime being introduced could lead to Airbnb rentals being banned in tenement flats with shared stairs.:Coronavirus: Edinburgh Airbnb flats help solve homelessness crisisConcerns have been raised over the restart of the short term lets industry in Edinburgh from July , when restrictions were lted for the tourism industry.Residents and campaigners had pleaded for short term lets to remain closed with the virus still a threat to public health, but Mr Stewart warned there were ldquono grounds for delaying the reopening of self-catering accommodation with shared facilities.He added: ldquoI understand the concerns of Edinburgh residents in tenements, and others with shared facilities, but we have to be guided by the medical and scientic advice.In a letter to Holyroodrsquos local government committee, Mr Stewart has confirmed that ldquohaving paused work on the regulation of short-term lets to deal with the pandemic, we have now resumed our work.He added: ldquoWe aim to lay the regulations giving local authorities powers to license short-term lets and introduce control areas in December so that they can be in force by spring .ldquoAs part of preparation to do this, we will be engaging stakeholders on our detailed proposals in autumn.ldquoThe delay caused by Covid- necessitates that this will be a shorter period of engagement than originally planned but we will make sure that the process is effective in refining our proposals and finalising the statutory instruments.The new powers will allow councils the ability to to introduce short term lets control areas, and to ldquocarefully and urgently review the tax treatment of short-term lets, which would ldquoensure they make an appropriate contribution to local communities and support local services, Mr Stewart added.:Council set to take over short-term lets in the capital and use them as homeless accommodationEdinburgh City Council has previously published what it would like to see in a licensing regime, including the ability cap the number of short term lets in certain parts of the city and ensuring properties comply with health and safety rules - while addressing residentsrsquo complaints over anti-social behaviour.The councilrsquos housing convener, Kate Campbell, said: ldquoWersquove identied that licensing is the best route for us to be able to properly control short term lets and prevent the negative impacts that they have had on our city and our residents.ldquoWersquoll continue to take action through planning, addressing antisocial behaviour and frankly any route open to us, but we know the game changer for Edinburgh will be a licensing regime. So wersquore delighted that this work is progressing at the Scottish Parliament and we will get the powers we need to protect homes and communities."But politicians have warned that the plans will not go far enough to halt the impact the industry is reportedly having on communities.Scottish Greens housing spokesperson, Andy Wightman, has led calls for greater regulation of short term lets.He said: ldquoThe Covid crisis has really shone a light the impact of unlawful short term lets, especially where they occur in shared buildings. Any licensing scheme needs to be robust and recognise the impact this poorly regulated market has had on housing provision, as well as the impact these properties have on the surrounding community.ldquoThe Scottish Government proposals must go further. For example, itrsquos clear that no licenses should be issued unless proper planning consent is in place. Each successful application is another home taken out of use, so councils must have the ability to reject applications based on the impact on their jurisdiction.Labour local government spokesperson, Sarah Boyack, added: ldquoI welcome the fact that ministers have listened to concerns about the potential delay to the introduction of new licensing powers for short term lets to local authorities and have resumed work on their proposals.ldquoThe key issue is that the control areas which local councils will have the power to establish will deliver effective regulation and accountability."ldquoWe have an urgent shortage of housing in Edinburgh so I will be keen to see the details proposed by ministers to deliver the taxation promised to ensure ldquoan appropriate contribution to local communities and support local services given the massive pressure council finances are currently facing due to years of underfunding.Before the pandemic, a new study revealed that almost one in five homes on Skye is listed on Airbnb.But tourism leaders on the island have warned that any draconian rules could hit businesses as it attempts to recover from the Covid- crisis.A spokesman for SkyeConnect said: ldquoIt is hard to project ahead to this time next year but we would like to think the Scottish Government would recognise the strain that has been placed on the tourism industry this year and not add an additional administrative burden for next season.ldquoShort-term lettings are a signicant part of the tourism economy on Skye and we recognise there are some issues which will need to be addressed. However, we are not convinced a licensing system is necessarily the way forward and we need time to consider other options."ldquoIn general terms, SkyeConnect is actively promoting a more slow-paced and sustainable visitor experience where people stay longer and experience more of the landscape, culture and history of Skye.

title: arts-reputations-liberation
story: The Daily MailSarah Vine asked why she is allowed to fly to Torremolinos in a tightly packed metal tube, breathing in other peoplersquos fumes for the best part of three hours solid mdash but am prevented from sitting in an air-conditioned auditorium "Itrsquos not just illogical, itrsquos absurd," she said. "Especially given whatrsquos at stake. Of all the things I miss about the old le, live culture is perhaps the greatest."She said that, enjoyable as Netflix is, nothing beats the excitement of a live performance."There is an intimacy and honesty to live performance that screen pixels, however slick, can never quite match, a human connection that feels so very vital mdash particularly now itrsquos gone," she added. "Therersquos something  too, of course: If we donrsquot find a way mdash any way mdash of getting our venues open again and our audiences cheering, we risk turning our rich, cultural scene into a barren desert."In order to try and help save the situation, Andrew Lloyd Webber staged an invitation only Beverley Knight concert in the London Palladium, she said, with  people in a , capacity venue, complete with one-way system, temperature checks and rows of seats sealed off.It feels weird to be sitting alone, surrounded by empty chairs," she said. "I clap a bit and nod my head dutully in time to the music mdash but feel stupid and exposed." Lloyd Webberrsquos message is clear: theatres cannot survive under these conditions. For any show to break even it has to run at least  per cent capacity. Todayrsquos auditorium is at  per cent."If the Government doesnrsquot give theatres the same freedoms as restaurants, pubs, gyms, tattoo parlours and the rest, they may never re-open ... and Covid will have destroyed our culture."The Frederick Forsyth said the Government is shuddering at the now unpreventable appearance of a penetrating and impartial assessment of the past seven months."More peacocks and more reputations are sheltering behind the pretence that the Covid outbreak was skilfully handled," he said. "But the politicos are the tip of the iceberg and can claim they were only following the best advice, or, as they put it "following the science"."He said the post-mortem report will reveal that people were conned into unnecessary panic, with mind-numbing propaganda and economic ruin by blitheringly incompetent administrators, bumbling quangos and "scientists" straight out of the annals of Mystic Meg.He said the unstoppable release of the report would lead to the fall of the hard rain referred to by Dominic Cummings."It is an attempt to persuade the panic and the consequent frightened obedience to stupid rules to continue that lies behind the new "scientic predictions" of a massive autumn spike in Covid," he added. "Those analysts who were rebuffed early on, and who were proved to be right, are saying this will be mainly the annual seasonal winter flu wave. This has been a tragic but never nation-destroying phenomenon for many, many years. The chances are that these losses will be presented to us as Covid deaths - to preserve reputations on high."The IndependentCaroline Harrap said the reaction to the mandatory wearing of face masks from yesterday in England was mixed at best."As someone who is prone to the occasional bout of anxiety, I feared it would affect my ability to breatheor make myself understood ," she said. "But then, in Morrisons the other day, something strange happened. As I strolled down the fruit and veg aisle, pondering my newfound anonymity, I felt a sudden sense of liberation rather than restriction."Who could seeshe bought two packs of fries, she said, when no one could actually see her "Hidden behind a mask, everyone is equal in the supermarket ndash regardless of their purchasing choices," she said.And, on another level, she feels free to go about her business without being judged on her appearance by others, male or female."A bit like wearing a school unorm, I suppose, suddenly we are all starting from the same place," she said."Wearing a face mask is, as it turns out, a great leveller."

title: liberal-democrats-must-support-union-win-votes
story: Layla Moran, who is in the running to be the partyrsquos next leader, also said the work of the Scottish LibDems should be mimicked nationallythey are to succeed in the next elections.Ms Moran, a former maths and physics teacher is hoping to replace Jo Swinson as the partyrsquos next leader and beat rival Ed Davey to the top job.Speaking exclusively to the Herald ahead of tomorrowrsquos virtual Scottish husting, she said: ldquoIn general elections weve had mega disappointment. Actually, you could even argue that  wasnt great because we lost seats.ldquoAll credit to the Scottish party for bucking the trend though. When we lost seats in England, actually we held or increase seats in Scotland and thats all credit to Willie Rennie and the amazing team under him. The Lib Dems have not just survived theyve thrived [in Scotland] but we also need to recognize that the national party is a drag.:Boris Johnson denies politicising coronavirus to boost the UnionMs Moran said in the next election, under her leadership, the party would ldquohave to find a way of stopping the SNP from using the next election as a way to tear the country apart.She explained: ldquo Instead, it could be used as a way of deepening federalism, which is what I believe, and would continue to advocate. From our inception we spoke about federalism, the USP of the Lib Dems is our local approach to politics.ldquoAt a time when people are trying to sow isions between Scotland and England I would argue this is the time that we should have even closer cooperation.ldquo Coronavirus has shown us that actually, we can work effectively together.Ms Moran said it was ldquoa real shame that Boris Johnson chose not to meet Nicola Sturgeon when he visited Orkney on Thursday, and added: ldquoWhy isnt he meeting Nicola Sturgeon to talk about the big issue of the day  Instead they are politicking, they need to grow up.As with other anti-independence parties, the LibDems will need to decide how to approach the constitutional question ahead of the next poll.Ms Moran said she believes taking the emotional approach to having a united kingdom should be the way forward for her party, explaining: ldquoIf we are going to fight the Tories effectively and alsowere going to fight the SNP effectively, the Liberal Democrats need to make that emotional argument for the union.ldquoThe way we do that is by really appealing to peoples sense of working together, as we have.ldquoWeve always had a completely consistent message on this as liberals. If you want to tackle the big issues of the day, the best way you do that is by finding your friends and working with them.ldquoI care about the care homes in Scotland as much as I care about care home in England. I care about the ability for every person to thrive, no matter where they are in the United Kingdom, and by spreading out that wealth by looking after each other, it speaks to a deeper value.ldquoThat emotional case is not being made loudly enough. The constitutional question needs to be bigger than what Nicola Sturgeon and Boris Johnson are using against each other.ldquoHersquos saying lsquoI give you all the money, you should be gratefulrsquo and shes basically saying lsquoWell, were going to go out on our own and look, were doing so much better actually.rsquoldquoIts not one or the other.:New Yes party inflames tensions within the SNPOn Russia, which has dominated the political agenda in the last fortnight, Ms Moran said she would condemn anyone appearing on Russian state-funded media, such as RT or Sputnik, but fell short of saying she would ban her own MPs from doing so.She explained: ldquoI dont know, mainly because I dont like banning things.ldquoRussia Today and Sputnik are awful and the Russian regime definitely doesnt need any more help with airtime. The Lib Dems shouldnt be helping them.ldquoI would suggest thatthere is someone in the party who wants to do it that theyll be spoken to , to explain why its a terrible idea and then they just wouldnt do it.ldquoIm generally not one for banning things unless youve had a conversation where you try and get them to see since first.The MP said she has turned down invitations by RT to appear on the channel, and said former First Minister Alex Salmond should no longer be involved with the broadcaster.She said: ldquoIf he was in my party Id be feeling very, very embarrassed. It shows an extraordinary lack of judgment from any politician to be doing Russia Today let alone taking money from them. Its ridiculous that its happening.Ms Moran will find outshe has succeeded in her leadership bid after the partyrsquos voting closes on August .

title: museum-wants-collect-covid-memorabilia
story: But evenwe canrsquot stomach dwelling on the mayhem caused by Covid-, the way Glaswegians have dealt with one of the greatest of health challenges will be preserved in a wide-ranging museum archive for future generations to explore.Glasgow Museums is gathering an eclectic mix of items that will encapsulate how Covid- has impacted on citizens to tell the story of the  pandemic from a uniquely city perspective.To help, social history curators have called for Glaswegians to help them collect objects for a coronavirus archive that will reflect the health crisis, the cityrsquos response and the impact it has had on inidual lives.Items in the collection are likely to range from heart-warming examples of childrenrsquos rainbow artwork that appeared as a symbol of hope and thanks to NHS Scotland, handmade face masks, and items such as hand sanitisers and PPE kit made by the cityrsquos businesses for the crisis.Itrsquos also hoped to gather handmade items made to keep hands and minds busy during the darkest days, and ephemeral items many of us may have already thrown away, such as letters and leaflets delivered to homes by the UK Government and the Scottish Government, childrenrsquos lockdown schoolwork and posters that inform of shop or business closures, cancelled events or which celebrate key workers.ldquoCoronavirus is a massive thing that has affected all of our lives and will have knock-on effects for years to come, said Isabel McDonald, curator of social history at Glasgow Museums. ldquoItrsquos really important to document it.ldquoIt might not be something that people particularly want to revisit quickly, but in years to come people will want to know what it was like.ldquoItrsquos important to be able to reflect on this time, and to have things that show what it was like.Glasgow Museums, including the Riverside transport museum , is preparing to archive items linked to the pandemic with a view to future exhibitions, she added.Photographs of a city in lockdown are likely to form a major part of the collection, along with items that just a few months ago were far from everyday le but which have become part of the ldquonew norm, such as face masks.A series of vivid posters created by art group Cobalt Collective that celebrated key workers is also expected to feature in the final collection alongside south side artist Libby Walkerrsquos drawings of people at home during lockdown.Posted on her Instagram page, they show stressed out home workers, people exercising in front rooms, bored children and others embracing the lockdown experience by pitching a ldquofestival tent in the living room, gaming or walking the dog.Archivists have also called for diaries of the lockdown experience, while it is also expected an oral history will also be recorded. They are particularly keen to gather items that help illustrate childrenrsquos experiences of the pandemic.ldquoWe are looking to capture the overall experience of lockdown, that we can look back on in the future and reflect on, and show future generations of the impact the pandemic had on Glasgow and its people, said Fiona Hayes,ldquoSome items have become iconic and symbolise the pandemic, such as the rainbow paintings that appeared in windows all over the city.ldquoWe are beginning to see the impact on businesses and jobs, and we want to record these changes. We have a duty to make sure we are recording what is happening using objects and peoplersquos experiences.The museum service has asked for people with offers of objects to email with details and photographs first, so its curators can decide what might be suitable and arrange for them to be acquired when it is safe to do so.Duncan Dornan, head of Glasgow Museums, said: ldquoWe are acutely aware Glasgowrsquos museum collection is an important part of who we are as iniduals and part of our identity as a city.ldquoCollections in archives, libraries and museums are the most reliable and engaging records of previous crisis. They also help us to understand and come to terms with the present by comparison with the past. Itrsquos important our collections react to the coronavirus situation with a carefully considered approach to collecting, which will support the interest of future generations.ldquoIn time this will allow people to look back and understand what we are currently experiencing.l If you would like to donate something that sums up your experience please send a few words and,possible, a photograph to: museums@glasgowle.org.uk

title: disney-postpones-mulan-remake-release-date-covid-cases-spike
story: It was part of a wider reshuffle by the entertainment giant, as it also pushed back four Avatar films and three untitled Star Wars movies.Disneyrsquos delays appeared to trigger similar announcements from other majorHollywood studios.Sony revealed the upcoming Spider-Man sequel starring Tom Holland had been delayed by a month to take advantage of Avatar  vacating the Christmas  slot.It will now swing into cinemas on December  , and not November  as previously scheduled.Top Gun: Maverick, a follow-up to Tom Cruisersquos  classic, was then pushed by Paramount from December   to July  next year.And A Quiet Place II, an early casualty of the pandemic in March, has now been delayed from September to April  .This is the fourth delay for Mulan, which was on the verge of release on March  when the pandemic closed theatres around the world.Disney then moved it to July  before switching to its most recent date of August .Mulan, which stars Lui Yei in the lead role, has now been postponed indefinitely.A Disney representative said: ldquoOver the last few months, itrsquos become clear that nothing can be set in stone when it comes to how we release films during this global health crisis, and today that means pausing our release plans for Mulan as we assess how we can most effectively bring this film to audiences around the world.Disney also pushed back a stream of other releases. James Cameronrsquos Avatar  - a sequel to the  film that was at the time the highest-grossing movie ever - has been delayed a year to December .The other films in the franchise will be released every other December, Disney said, finishing with Avatar  in .Three Star Wars films were also delayed. The first untitled movie has shted from December  to a year later, while the two others will be released in December  and December  respectively.The superhero movie will now be released in the US on December   and not November  as previously scheduled, the studio announced.Other films delayed by Disney include Sir Ridley Scottrsquos historical thriller The Last Duel, which stars Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. That has shted from December of this year to October .However, not all of Disneyrsquos films were shted to next year.Sir Kenneth Branaghrsquos adaptation of Agatha Christiersquos Death On The Nile was pushed back two weeks to October  .The Mulan delay is another bitter blow to the ailing cinema industry, following Warner Brosrsquo decision to push back Christopher Nolanrsquos much-anticipated blockbuster Tenet.Theatre owners had hoped both movies would entice customers back through the doors after months of lockdown.While cinemas in England were allowed to reopen from July  - as long as social distancing guidelines were followed - the picture across North America is much more uncertain.New York City and Los Angeles, the two biggest markets in the US, have no concrete plans for reopening cinemas.

title: equal-pay-pension-bungle-women-asked-pay-back-thousands-pounds-overpayments
story: Hundreds of women, who have already retired, were due more in their pension to reflect the earnings they should have had in the years when they were underpaid compared to men in similar roles.However, a mistake in the pension settlement re-calculations has seen some overpaid as much as pound, plus in some cases and others underpaid by the same amount.While all were due ying amounts the highest overpayment is understood to be in the region of pound,.The pensioners were informed of the correct amount in a revised statement but were paid the wrong amount into their bank account.For every person paid more someone  was paid the same amount less.The cash has been transferred into bank accounts this week but now they have been told of the error and asked to repay the cash.Those who were underpaid are being contacted to tell them to expect more.The mistake means that payments were mixed up and  people were underpaid and  were overpaid by the same amount.Strathclyde Pension Fund has apologised and is contacting everyone affected.In total  equal pay women, who had retired by the time the settlement was reached were in the category of having their pension re-evaluated and were due more cash.The council had to pay poundmillion in employer contributions and the women poundm in total.It meant they had to have their employee contributions deducted from their settlement and were due increased contributions to their pension from the council.It also that they had been underpaid in the lump sum they took on retirement and a revised settlement was being worked out.A spokesman for Strathclyde Pension Fund, said: ldquoClearly, an error has been made and we are very sorry for the worry and inconvenience this will have caused to some of those affected.ldquoWe are making contact with them, inidually, to explain what has happened and ensure they get the payment they are entitled to.Strathclyde Pension Fund has been calculating the impact on the pension pots of all claimants who are or were members of the Local Government Pension Scheme and their pensions were re-rated during this month.A spokesman for Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoSettling Glasgowrsquos historic equal pay cases also had an impact on the pensions of a number of current and former staff ndash and, for some, that means the lump sums they received when they retired should have been higher.ldquoIn total, the settlement included pound million in additional pension contributions ndash including employer contributions of pound million from the council.

title: 18th-century-observatory-converted-artistic-retreat
story: The historic observatory complex on Calton Hill, Edinburgh, dates back to , but i is set to become a base for international artists to stay in when they are visiting the city.The landmark, which overlooks Edinburgh, has lain empty for years and previously had ldquobuilding at risk status.But it was taken over by the Collective Gallery two years ago and the charity has now revealed plans to restore the A-listed Old Observatory House.Under a planned pound, makeover, artists and craft-makers will be commissioned to make new works for the building, which will be ided into two separate apartments.A neglected courtyard will be turned into an outdoor seating area under designs for the arts organisation by Glasgow-based Collective Architecture.Plans lodged with the city council state: ldquoThe level of signicance for this building is multi-layered a combination of fine architectural detailing, an architect of great signicance to Edinburgh, strong scientic links to the development of astronomy and timekeeping in the city, forming part of a group of the nationrsquos most signicant buildings.As well as accommodating visiting artists, the two apartments will also be able for hire for corporate events and as holiday homes. New kitchens will be installed to allow ldquofine dining experiences to be created by the neighbouring restaurant The Lookout.Collective director Kate Gray said: ldquoObservatory House is a gem of a building in an incredible location.ldquoThough this is a challenging time as we emerge from an extended closure and are struggling with the loss of expected income, it is even more important that we move forward to complete the full integration of our historic site.ldquoGiving the house a new lease of le as a letable space will allow us to generate income that will help keep Collective freely accessible to all.Emma Fairhust, lead architect on the project, said: ldquoOld Observatory House is a beautul building, full of character and interest.ldquoWe plan to keep the rooms simple and calm and to retain the feeling of the house as a retreat, overlooking the busy city below.

title: august reopening for kirkwall tourist centre
story: coronavirusAugust reopening for Kirkwall tourist centreJuly ,  at : pmKirkwall#s tourist information centre is set to reopen, next month, VisitScotland has confirmed.As tourism begins to resume across the country, VisitScotland has announced that it will be reopening its iCentres on a rolling basis, starting today, Monday.Kirkwall iCentre is one of  due to reopen in August.The phased approach is due to the team at VisitScotland having to make internal changes to every one of the nation#s   iCentres to ensure that they are adapted for physical distancing, but also to continue to give visitors a warm welcome. There will be a range of safety features installed including Perspex screens, hand sanitisers and signage to ensure physical distancing with some dates possible to change on the dependence of materials and suppliers.    The reopened iCentres will initially only offer an information service to visitors with the hope of reintroducing ticketing, accommodation booking and retail as soon as safe to do so. Throughout the lockdown, VisitScotland’s information service never really closed with iCentre staff delivering visitor information through a range of other channels including a new messenger service, an iCentre telephone and email service, as well as other customer channels.    Manuela Calchini, Head of Information at VisitScotland said:  “Our iCentre staff have been working to get the centres reopened and are looking forward to being able to help visitors with face to face enquiries for the first time in four months.   #The information services never really closed however, and I’d like to pay tribute to the team for all its hard work in getting to this point.“Our iCentres are a signicant part of the community and we understand that there will be a desire to open them as soon as possible — we share that desire and want to support the tourism industry and communities as we come out of lockdown, however the safety of our staff and visitors is paramount.”   copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: children under five eligible for covid 19 test from july 22
story: Children under the age of five who are displaying potential COVID- symptoms will be eligible for testing from Wednesday, July .Currently, children under five who have potential COVID- symptoms are not routinely tested and a test is only carried outthere is a pressing clinical need to do so.Now, with childcare settings reopening from July , children aged under five who have COVID- symptoms will be eligible for routine testing through all routes.COVID- testing for all children under  years old should be completed by their parent or carer.Interim chief medical officer Gregor Smith said: “In light of the continued change in lockdown restrictions and the resumption of early learning and childcare, we have reviewed our testing policy for children under five.“We want to avoid households having to isolate unnecessarilyyoung children in their family are displaying coronavirus-like symptoms which can be common in this age group.“I would encourage anyone who has symptoms of COVID- or whose child has symptoms, to get a test immediately to help us suppress the spread of the virus.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
